SHIPPING INTELLIGENCE.
FREIGHTS.
During the past week there has been a further rise in freights from the Baltic, and high rates are paid for deals from the lower ports. The demand for London for steamers, which was so brisk last week, has been paid this season. There are, however, some boats still holding out for higher rates, notwithstanding the frequent warnings they receive by merchants, "unless they moderate their rates they will find their vessels un-shipped" that has happened to so many vessels this fall. This rise in freights is from 15s. to 17s. 6d. to 20s. per standard. Last week some vessels were secured from the lower Canadian ports on this side at 35s. hewn timber, and 115s. sawn timber. From Doboy, for a full range of pitch pine, the following bills of lading are current:-
Annexed are current freights:-
Gefle or District to London, 42s. 6d. to 45s.

St. JOHN, N.B.-A circular from a firm of direct English correspondents says:-
PENSACOLA.-A correspondent writing under circular dated August 31st, says:-
"Since date of our last circular there has been little activity in freights, and this is partly accounted for by the scarcity of tonnage offering for early loading, and consequently by the high rates asked by owners. Freights to United Kingdom have ruled firm, and ready vessels could command full rates. For the coastwise, 9.50 dols. to 10 dols. has been paid, but a rates is apparent, and we now quote 10.50 dols. to 11.50 dols. to New York, Boston, or Philadelphia. Side. Engagements for forward loading have been made in Europe at £5 15s. to £6."
QUEBEC.-Sept. 10. For Greenock, 2,000 pcs. oak, 20s.; 1,075 pcs. elm, 20s.; 2,460 pine deals, 50s. For Bristol, 2,000 pcs. pine, 1,075 deals, 50s. For Plymouth, 24,000 pcs. pine, 1,075 deals, 50s.
